unnormalised: Hey there, someone asked about the hierarchy in the Indian Army. It can be a bit confusing, so lemme break it down simply. At the very top, you've got the COAS, or Chief of the Army Staff. He's a Gen, a 4-star general, basically the big boss of the whole shebang. Directly under him, you will usually find senior Lt Gens heading various commands.
normalised: Hey there, someone asked about the hierarchy in the Indian Army. It can be a bit confusing, so let me break it down simply. At the very top, you've got the C-O-A-S, or Chief of the Army Staff. He's a General, a four-star general, basically the big boss of the whole shebang. Directly under him, you will usually find senior Lieutenant Generals heading various commands.

unnormalised: Then comes the Lt Gen, Lieutenant General, who heads an entire Command. Beneath them are Maj Gens or Major Generals, who typically command Divisions. Brigadiers command Brigades and Colonels are in charge of Regiments or Battalions depending on its strength. Its crucial to know that some units may not follow all standard ranks - some units are headed by an officer 1 rank above (or below, rarely) the position.

unnormalised: Below the commissioned officers we start seeing the JCOs or Junior Commissioned Officers like Subedar Majors and Subedars. These guys are experienced soldiers, often with decades of service. Then you've got your Havildars, Naiks and Lance Naiks leading sections or platoons. And of course, the backbone of it all, the Sepoys – the regular soldiers.
